Green tiles are only viewable by you, the teacher. White tiles are what your students see. To hide the green tiles, click the "Solutions" toggle above right.

You can use these green tiles for

  • guidance for yourself as you present to a class
  • guidance for your students to use — by editing them (drag them across to your workspace) and then publishing your version to the class

MothEd CLUE Support Materials Online

For a general overview of CLUE's usefulness and links to helpful approaches and documents, see CLUE with MothEd.

For how to create classes and assign this activity see Getting Started in CLUE for MothEd Teachers.

An extensive guide to CLUE aimed at students (but also useful for you!) is the My Moths in CLUE Guide.

How to Navigate CLUE (linked at the top of this section) is a one-page, handout-style "Pro Tips" guide for students.

On the right is your Workspace. To edit your Workspace, you must first add a tile. You get a tile in your Workspace by either

  • Dragging a tile from the content (left side) in CLUE into your Workspace
  • Dragging a new tile from the menu on the left of your Workspace
  • Click a button on the menu to add a new tile to the bottom of your Workspace

To drag a tile to your workspace, hover over it with your cursor and use the gray triangle with six dots that appears in the upper right corner. Click the triangle and hold it down as you drag it to your Workspace. As you drag the tile into the Workspace, a light blue line shows where the tile will go when you let go (next to, above, below).

Sharing Ideas

In CLUE, everyone works in a group with up to four people. When you start an activity, CLUE suggests a group randomly or asks you to start a new group. You can do either: then, change groups by clicking on the group number in the upper right corner. Join your table's group.

Groups are important in CLUE. You can learn from table-mates in your group and they can learn from you. Many features of CLUE are designed to help you share information and learn from others in your group and in your class.

Question: What would happen if all of the moths disappeared?

Drag this tile to your Workspace and write down potential ideas to answer the question above. If you think of more questions as you are answering this question, record them in a new text tile.

You can use CLUE tools to lead students through Think-Pair-Sharing activities. Have them:

  • create a text tile and brainstorm on their own, then
  • talk with their table mate as a pair, and then
  • toggle the "Share" button on the top right and open the group icon to widen the discussion.

Brainstorm some research questions about moths

What do you want to know more about? Take time to think about it and write potential ideas in a new text tile. Discuss with a partner.
You may want to assign a "recorder" in each group to publish the groupsʻ list next. That way there arenʻt too many lists to view in the Classwork tab.

When ready, share with the group

  1. Use the group controls to see and share each others' ideas (see image below).
  2. Discuss the questions with your group and
  3. Combine your ideas into one list of your best questions.
  4. Publish your group's idea list to the class.
